title: Disabled boy killed by chicken nugget after school ignored order to cut his food
text:
Kedar Williams, who had severe autism, choked to death on a chicken nugget while at school. His mother Michelle said workers ignored a plan stipulating that all Kedar’s food be cut into manageable chunks (Pictures: Legacy.com)

A disabled teenager choked to death on a chicken nugget after a school worker ignored a plan advising all the boy’s food be cut up.

Kedar Williams, 19, died on the second day of school in August after he was left unsupervised at lunch, and got one of the nuggets stuck in his trachea.

Kedar had severe autism, with staff at William T Dwyer High School in Palm Beach, Florida, reportedly ignoring a special plan devised to keep Kedar safe.

His distraught mother Michelle Williams told the Palm Beach Post: ‘I tried very hard to make sure he had a normal life.

‘You should be good with sending your child to school. They should be protected while in school.

‘This is not something that should happen.

Kaden died in August, on the second day of the academic year at William T Dwyer High School, pictured (Picture: Google Maps)

‘I trusted them.

‘This is a nightmare. A nightmare.’

Michelle explained that Kedar’s plan stipulated that his food be cut into chunks, that each bite be washed down with a drink, that he should be offered help using the restroom and not allowed to wander alone.

But a medical examiner’s report said Kedar began choking on a large piece of food while a health aide was supervising him and another student in the school cafeteria.

It said that Kedar was eating nuggets when he got up abruptly and walked to a nearby window.

The report continued: ‘As he was returning to the table, he appeared in distress … (he) started gasping and he appeared to be choking.

‘He collapsed to the floor, and the health aid called for help.’

First aiders performed the Heimlich maneuver on Kedar, and managed to dislodge some food from his throat.

He was rushed to hospital, and declared dead around an hour after the incident began.

A supervisor who worked solely with Kedar was no longer able to do so from the day of his death.

That meant another aide was working with both Kedar and another student, despite the teenager’s plan stating he required one on one care.

Michelle Williams is outraged at what she says was neglect that led to her son’s death.

A medical examiner ruled that the tragedy was an accident.

Michelle Williams is now working with a lawyer to determine whether she can file a lawsuit against William T Dwyer High Scool.

A school spokesman declined to comment.
description: Kader Williams suffered severe autism, and needed constant supervision as well as food cut into manageable pieces. His mother Michelle blames the teenager's school for his tragic death
